content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Dr. Dorothy Irene Height, born in 1912, was a prominent civil rights activist known for her efforts in promoting equality, social justice, and human rights. She advocated for interracial schooling, voter registration, and women's visibility in society. Dr. Height also worked to improve the lives of inner-city children and played a significant role in advancing the rights of women and African Americans. Dr. Dorothy Irene Height, a prominent civil rights activist, had a public career spanning over 65 years. She was a valued consultant on human and civil rights issues to First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt and advocated for desegregation of schools. Dr. Height has been President of the National Council of Negro Women since 1957, leading 250 local and 38 national groups in economic development and women's issues. Under Dr. Height's leadership, the National Council of Negro Women implemented innovative programs including Operation Woman Power, leadership training for African-American women in the rural South, the Black Family Reunion, the Women's Center for Education and Career Advancement, and the Bethune Museum and Archives. Dr. Height has been a key figure in AIDS education and has helped establish offices in West Africa and South Africa to improve conditions for women. She has also played a central role in the success of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. and the Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA). Dr. Height's involvement in the civil rights movement, as the only female member of the "Big Six" leaders, led to integration and active participation. She received awards for her efforts in women's rights, including the Spingarn Award, Presidential Medal of Freedom, and John F. Kennedy Memorial Award. Dr. Height received several awards for her contributions to civil rights and women's rights, including the Ministerial Interfaith Association Award, Lovejoy Award, Ladies Home Journal Woman of the Year Award, William L. Dawson Award, and Citizens Medal Award. Dr. Dorothy Height received multiple awards for her contributions to civil rights and women's rights, including the Citizens Medal Award presented by President Reagan and the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Freedom Medal. She has established a lasting legacy of public service that has greatly benefited the nation. Dr. Dorothy Irene Height is authorized to receive a Congressional Gold Medal for her contributions to the nation. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the gold medal. Duplicates in bronze may be struck and sold under regulations set by the Secretary. The gold medal holds national status. The medals authorized under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. An amount not to exceed $30,000 is authorized to be charged against the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund to pay for the cost of the medal. Amounts received from the sale of duplicate bronze medals shall be deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund.
